solution.text:
Area of the quadrilateral(PQRS) = area of the \(\bigtriangleup \) PSR + \(\bigtriangleup \) PQR
So for Right angled \(\bigtriangleup \) PQR, we have PQ=9L, QR=40L and PR=\(\sqrt {PQ^2+QR^2}\) (Pythagoras theorem)
So we get PR=\(\sqrt {(9L)^2+(40L)^2}=\sqrt {1681L^2}=41L\)
For Right-angled triangle we can find the area directly by using \(\frac 12 \times base \times altitude \)
So area \(\bigtriangleup \) PQR= \(\frac 12 \times 40L \times 9L=180L^2=180\times _{j}_^2\)
\(\Rightarrow _{{180*j*j}}_\)
Now for \(\bigtriangleup \) PSR we have we have PS=28L, SR=15L and PR=41L
By using Heron's formula, area of PSR = \(\sqrt {s(s-a_1)(s-b_1)(s-c_1)}\) where \(a_1\),\(b_1\),\(c_1\) are the sides of the triangle and \(s=\frac {a_1+b_1+c_1}2 \)
Here \(PS=a_1=28L\),\(SR=b_1=15L\) and \(PR=c_1=41L\) so \(s=\frac {28L+15L+41L}2=42L\)
Therefore, area \(\bigtriangleup \) PSR= \(\sqrt {42L(42L-28L)(42L-15L)(42L-41L)} = L^2\times \sqrt {42\times 14\times 27\times 1}=9\times 14 \times L^2=126\times L^2\)
\(\Rightarrow _{{126*j*j}}_\)
Hence area of the quadrilateral PQRS = area of the \(\bigtriangleup \) PQR + \(\bigtriangleup \) PSR= _{{j*j*180}}_ + _{{j*j*126}}_
\(\Rightarrow _{{306*j*j}}_\)

content.text: In the quadrilateral PQRS, PQ=9L, QR=40L, RS=15L, SR=28L where 9L denotes 9 \(\times \) L and similarly in other sides and the value of L=_{j}_.
